segments.text: This is an interview with Leland C. Johnson by Tracy L. Swope on 4 December in Temple concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is this all right with you?
Yes.
If you would, please, give us some background on where you were born, where you went to school, and how you joined the service.
I was raised in Colorado.
pretty much on a farm.
My father had spent several years in the Air Force, well, the Army when he started in the Air Force when he got out.
I ran out of money my freshman year of college, and I couldn't find any part-time work.
I could find lots of full-time work, and I ran into Master Sergeant Kingrey, who was the Army recruiter.
I enlisted into the Army to go to the Warrant Flight Program
while I was in basic training they set it up so that you enlisted directly into it and by the time I got out of basic training there was a two year waiting list to get into the program.
I went to jump school and reported out to Okinawa to the 173rd Airborne Brigade separate as my first assignment.
I made buck sergeant E-5, 22 minutes later
for 22 months after going into the service and had applied for OCS.
Got orders to go to Fort Benning, Georgia to the infantry officers candidate school in February of 1965.
I was commissioned in August of 1965
While I was in OCS, the 173rd and the 3rd Marine Division deployed off of Okinawa to Vietnam.
I requested relief from OCS to go back to my unit and it was denied after a long father to son counseling session with my company commander.
Went out to Fort Bragg and assumed a
platoon leader's job with the rifle company.
Stayed on that for about 90 days and because of my prior enlisted experience with mortars and heavy weapons, I had moved up to the headquarters company and took over the heavy mortar platoon.
On two occasions they took all my troops away from me except for myself, my platoon sergeant and one FDC sergeant
and gave us kids right out of basic training to retrain.
After having done that with the second batch and got them qualified, I managed to convince the Department of Army to send me to Vietnam.
And I reported into Vietnam in July of 1966 with the first set of major replacements for the 173rd.
Go ahead.
What was your feelings about flying in and realizing you were going into combat?
I wanted to go.
I volunteered.
I was anxious to go.
I had been in the Army at this point in time for about four years and had never been shot at.
And we had done all these little maneuvers with blank ammunition and I wanted to see what it was like for real.
Basically to see whether I had what it took.
My initial experience getting shot at as a platoon leader was that you were too busy to be scared.
It wasn't until after things got over with that you were scared.
Where were you stationed in Vietnam?
We operated primarily in three corps, in Rung Sat Special Zone, in Iron Triangle, and over close to
the Cambodian border.
At the end of that tour we moved up to two corps and relieved a brigade of the fourth division that was basically non-deployable.
Which was, I left just before the 173rd lost a battalion
off the mountain with two officers and 80 enlisted men left out of a whole battalion.
What was your mission when you were there with your platoon?
Well, early on we were primarily looking for Vietnamese guerrillas.
And these were basically guys that were farmers in the daytime and guerrillas at night.
And we beat them at their own game.
We took a lot of casualties from booby traps, but we basically cleaned them out of the area that we were operating in.
And it was towards the end of the tour that we started running into conventional forces or NVA regulars.
And that's when the tone of the war changed a whole lot.
They were bringing in outside supplies and outside personnel and bringing them down a Ho Chi Minh trail.
It wasn't us against a bunch of farmers.
It was us against well-disciplined, well-armed, well-equipped troops.
What would an average day be there like?
Stand two before first light.
That would go until about 30 minutes after first light.
We'd put out patrols, bring in our listening posts,
Everybody would eat breakfast on the run, and then we would move.
Sometimes we'd have something we were looking for, and sometimes we were just stumbling around in the jungle trying to see what we could stir up.
We'd move all day long, sometimes as a unit, sometimes in small squad-sized patrols on a fan.
Generally, we would not operate.
We wouldn't move at night, although sometimes we did.
and we'd dig in an hour before last night and put out listening posts.

Many times we'd put out what they called Malaysian fan ambushes where I'd break my platoon down into a lot of four and five man ambush teams and we'd ambush a whole pattern of trails so that if they came in from any direction we'd have two or three separate ambushes that would catch them as they came through
and we were able to interdict and kill a great many of the guerrilla forces.
When we got into where we were doing battle with NVA, they operated in larger strength which caused us to change our tactics considerably and we had more platoon size ambushes than 4 and 5M ambushes.
Do you remember your first day going out in the field?
My first day, I reported them, dropped off my duffel bag, picked up a rucksack.
The company was out in the field.
I was handed two soldiers to take out to the field that had reported in late from R&R and had been somewhat reluctant to go back out to the field.
And we hitchhiked, the helicopter rides out.
delivered these two characters to the first sergeant, reported to my company commander, and by this time it's about four o'clock in the afternoon.
Company commander tells me that I'm replacing a lieutenant who had just been shot, or stepped on a mine about seven or eight hours before.
My platoon sergeant gives me a walk of our portion of the perimeter very hurriedly, and

I can tell he's in some kind of a hurry, and I don't really understand why, but anyway, after we spend time and I ask questions about machine guns and placement and all that and decide he knows what he's doing, he allows us how I probably ought to put up my shelter for the night, which I did, and the only open piece of ground that was available.
And about the time I got my shelter half put up, it commenced to rain like I had never seen it rain before in my whole life.
And a little piece of ground that I had built my shelter around is not an open piece of ground, it's an intermittent stream.
And I commenced to have all my worldly possessions float away in two feet of water while all the troops laugh at the new green lieutenant.
And that was my introduction to Vietnam.
Do you remember the first time you were fired off?
You took fire?
No, I can't really say as I do.
Okay.
How did you feel about the enlisted men?
Did you develop a father-son type attitude, or?
Well, understand that I was 20 years old at the time.
I'll take that back.
I had just turned 21 before I reported into Vietnam.
My platoon sergeant was a guy I had known in Fort Bragg who was in the same company with me in the 82nd, who seemed to be older than Hills, I think he was probably 35 or 36.
Most of the kids that were over there were volunteers at least to the airborne, if not volunteers to be in
Vietnam and almost all of the officers and senior NCOs were volunteers on their first tour.

Most of us were excited, we believed in what we were doing, we thought we were better than anybody else at it, and there was a close-knit camaraderie that you get with special units like Special Forces, Marine Force Recon, Airborne
that were probably not typical of the average American infantry combat unit.
We didn't have major discipline problems.
We didn't have any drug problems.
We had, by and large, T or any strength for NCOs, although there were a few shortages.
And most of them were professional.
Good quality.
A lot of experience, although not in actual combat.
They had years of leading troops and were technically very proficient in what they were doing.
I'm not sure that answers your question.
Yes it does.
You were wounded over there, huh?
Twice.
Twice.
Do you have some highlights on that?
Once we were moving into Kordanoffa Village at night.
It was raining.
It's hard to describe in the United States how hard it can rain in Vietnam, but it literally was raining so hard that you could not see 15 feet.
We were moving through the jungle and the water was about a foot deep on the ground when you get any kind of a low place.
And we went in at night to move in and cordon off this village.
Either I was lost or the company commander was lost, but we ended up
dropping a 105 shell in my back pocket.
I picked up a small piece of steel, and helicopters being what they were, I was in a hospital 45 minutes later, and they picked it out.
Well, or tried to pick it out.
The nurses weren't as competent there as they could have been.
Ten days later I was out of the hospital and back with my platoon.
The second time we had a Malaysian fan ambush out and we knew that there were a lot of NVA and guerrillas working in the area.
I had my platoon busted down into five ambush teams on a series of trail intersections.
In those days we had two radios per platoon and I had one and the platoon sergeant had one.
but the ambushes on either side of me did not have a radio.
Clouds were hanging down where it was fog.
When you'd stand up, you were in the fog, and when you'd lay down on the ground, you could just barely see under.
About 4 o'clock in the morning, the five of us caught what looked to be about a 10-man carrying party coming through our trail.
And I opened up the ambush with full tracer, and everybody else started shooting.
I could tell by the way one of them fell that he probably wasn't dead.

And when it was all over, and I understand this whole interchange probably lasted about 20 seconds, I decided that we'd had the intelligence officer asking us for prisoners that probably could police this character up.
And I went over in the dark, and I could see an outline of where he was laying in the dark.
And I said something to him and he used it, which later I found I did not mean what I said I thought I did.
And he shot me with a Sub Thompson.
These TV westerns where you see where somebody gets shot with a .45 and he staggers around and gives his last will and testament is bullshit.
I did a complete somersault in the air before I hit the ground and I probably weighed about 20 pounds less than I do now.
But I was still about 200 pounds.
It made me mad.

I just, I got blind rage and I stood up and I put a whole magazine into him and I flipped it over and I put the other side of that magazine into him and I'm fumbling around in my ammo pouch to get a third magazine to put into him.
When the adrenaline started coming down and reason started coming back and it dawned on me that I was standing out in front of my own ambush, blazing away,
and I had no idea how many other of his guys were around, and I turned around and said, hold it, I'm coming back, it's me, and started to walk back.

Well, my leg gave way on me at that point in time, and I crawled back to where I was at, and it was still dark, I had no medic with me, and I'm feeling around on my leg, trying to find out where I'm hit, because it's
It doesn't really hurt.
It feels like somebody hit you in the leg with a sledgehammer.
You know it's going to hurt, but right now it's just numb.
And I lose these three fingers up to the second knuckle.
I said, well, it's probably just a flesh wound.
And I get out my battle dressing and I put it on and tighten it off.
And call in the company commander and tell him that we've had some contact and we've got several
the enemy dead, and some rice and a few weapons, and we've got one wounded.
And I'm trying to find a tackle way to tell him it's me again.
And finally I get up the courage enough to tell him that it was this dumb lieutenant that managed to get himself shot again.
And he said some words that we won't repeat on here.
This time we had such overcast that we couldn't get a helicopter in, even after it got light.
It was about noon before we could get a helicopter with a penetrator to come down through the canopy and get me out of there.

But after it got light, what we found out was that the bullet had gone in here and had come out over here, and what I thought was just a grazing wound was the exit wound, and at 45 it left a pretty good sized hole.
I was fortunate in that I did not lose my leg.
They yanked me out of there and hauled me to the hospital and debrided it.
And in about two weeks I got out of the hospital, although I wasn't walking too well.
They had given my platoon over my ejections to another lieutenant who might have been fairly well.
He managed to get himself seriously wounded about two weeks after that and was evacuated back to Fitzsimmons Army Hospital in Denver.
He got shot in the head and he was never really right after that.
My platoon sergeant and I had a relationship that was somewhat unique.
He was a Czechoslovakian.
who had been policed up as a young boy in the Second World War with the German labor force.
And during a B-17 raid over Germany, they had knocked a hole in the fence and he had managed to escape and steal a bicycle and evacuate E&E back to the British lines.
He joined the British Army and spent two or three years with them.
After a couple years with the British Army, Desation came to the United States and enlisted in the American Army.

He spoke German with the Berlin Iraqis and Czechoslovakian and several other Slavic languages and they put him in civilian clothes and sent him back to Berlin with special forces and after several years at that he had ended up with me and Fort Bragg
And he was an NCO acting as platoon leader and I was a lieutenant acting as platoon leader.
And he used to beat me hands down at every damn thing we had for competition.
We got to Vietnam and he ended up being my platoon sergeant.
His English was about the only language he didn't have full command of.
I was probably the only guy in the company that could understand him on the radio.

He had a bit of a drinking problem, and we had sort of an unwritten agreement that when we came back out of the field, the first 48 hours were D's, and I would run the platoon, and he would go up in some corner and get blown away for two days, and then he would come back stone cold sober and function with the platoon.
If there was any time left over, I got to goof off.
Unfortunately, when I briefed my lieutenant replacement on that, and he understood it,
But when he got shot, we got a new company commander by the same time.
And he called Dee in during the first 48 hours.
Dee showed up at a company commander's briefing for an operation, three sheets to the wind, and it took everything I could muster to keep him from getting court-martialed.
Dee later retired as a first sergeant, but it
took a lot of maneuvering to keep him from getting court-martialed after showing up at that damn briefing.
My relationships with the troops were probably not as close, although you felt it was a family.
You ate the same food they did, you suffered the same hardships they did,
You knew their girls and their wives and how many kids they had.
And when one of them got hurt, you hurt.
I don't think Vietnam was unique in that.
Any combat environment where you've got a group of men that are strongly dependent upon each other for their very existence, you get that kind of a bonding.
Did you have Vietnamese in your platoon, and if so, how did you feel about them?
First tour, I didn't have any Vietnamese in my platoon.
I went back as a company commander, second tour.
When was?
Let's see, I went back in July of 67 for my second tour, and I was a company commander.
I had Ket Carson scouts.
Now, this time I was with the 1st Air Cavalry Division,
and we were operating up in I-Corps and it went from the Street Without Joy area on the beach all the way back into the Esho Valley.
We had kit cars and scouts which were supposedly NVA that we had captured or guerrillas that we had captured and they had seen the light and now they were going to come work for us.
Some of them were good, some of them were dangerous.

We used them as interpreters, we used them to help give us a feel for what the NVA were likely to do, especially when we got into bunker complexes or something like that, they had a better feel and understanding
you know, within the unit.
We did not have integrated units.
When you were there the second time, it was after tech.
Did you run into a drug or racial problem there?
There's always been some racial problems in the services, because we draw our people out of civilian life, and they bring all of the
emotional baggage into the military with them.
I think that probably the services do a better job at putting everybody on an equal status than do most of the civilian environments, but yeah there was some racial problems there.
Not to the point where we had conflict.
My first sergeant was black.
Some of my NCOs were black.
a number of my troops were black, a number of them were Hispanic.
The only real problems we had were part of McNamara's 100,000.
Those weren't all black though, they were predominantly black because they came in.
Do you understand what McNamara's 100,000 is?
Okay.
We're talking about kids who are one standard deviation below the mean in terms of intelligence,

predominantly from inner cities, predominantly minorities, a lot of them with a chip on their shoulder, and because of their lack of any educational skills or skills of any kind, the biggest part of them ended up in the combat arms.
Most of them felt they'd been put in the combat arms because they were being picked on,

in most cases they had been put in the combat harness because they couldn't qualify for anything else we had some problems with them but nothing that causes any real loss of effectiveness in the company if we had any drug problems and i'm not naive enough to say that we didn't i was not aware of it while i was a company commander predominantly because
My kids came in, they dropped their duffel bags, we picked up a rucksack and they never saw Civilization again until they went on R&R.
They got one five day R&R in a year.
And that was their only real opportunity to buy drugs unless it was being mailed in and we did a pretty good job of keeping tabs on the mail.
I was there when the mail chompers came in and it was, you could see what was going on.
If anybody brought any grass or anything back, they didn't bring back enough to last them very long.
And I really believe that most of my troops would not have tolerated that in a combat environment.
And they didn't get back to a base camp operation.
The drug problems that became so famous in Vietnam were predominantly around
rear area units and units that operated out of a base camp most of the time.
And we just did not have access.
We stayed out in no man's land.
You left the second time.
How did you feel about leaving your men behind, or even the first time?
Well, rotation was an ongoing process.
And in the period of a year, you'd see your whole unit change.
It was everybody's time.
After I spent seven months with the company, I left the company.
and went to the battalion to serve as the intelligence officer.
So I hadn't really left them then as much as I had moved across the street from the battalion.
My departure from the company as the company commander was somewhat traumatic in that I was due to rotate and go on R&R and then come back and assume the position of the battalion S-2.

They had a new West Point captain that was coming in to take the company and the battalion commander came down and said he wanted to delay my R&R by two or three days so that I could go out and take one last mission.
The guys in G2 had developed some radio intercepts and some hotspots that they wanted me to go check out with my company.

And I said, yeah, that was no problem, but I wanted to go on R&R, and the old man said that he would let me have his helicopter to get to Da Nang a couple hours before the flight left, so that I could make R&R on schedule, because Jerry had already left the States.
Well, we C8 in to a Colville Z and started moving to where the radio intercepts were.
We ran into an old bunker complex that hadn't been used for looked like a year or two.
And then as we proceeded on farther north, all probably a quarter of a mile to half a mile, we started running into newer construction.
Simultaneously to my moving north, we had an assister company that was moving down to the south.
It was lost.
and they were reporting their position very close to me.
And I had put out the word to my point elements to identify positively before they fired on anything because we had one of our own companies moving in.
About that time, my point element reported that they were affecting link-up.
What we linked up with, unfortunately, was an NVA regiment
One company, which was in American uniforms, had American equipment, had newer American equipment than I had.
And I lost a whole platoon in about 30 seconds.
After that, they maneuvered on us.
And I had basically two line platoons and a mortar platoon.
and we did battle with what was the better part of a regiment for about four hours.

Fortunately, we brought in the air cab, the first cab division that had what they called aerial rocket artillery, which was a process for using gunship very much the way Marines use close air support, because we were out of conventional artillery range.
We got

gunship support and as I am trying to evacuate the rest of my wounded back out understand we made initial contact about one o'clock in the afternoon it gets dark over there at that time of the year about six and about 430 I have gotten most of my wounded out I've got three dead that are unaccounted for but I'm 95% sure I did
I've got myself, my artillery, forward observer, one medic, and my two RTOs with me.
I've lost one of my lieutenants who got shot as close to me as I'm sitting to you.
One of my lieutenants who is the one of about four or five survivors out of this
lead platoon that made the link up is virtually ineffective.
He's kind of gone off the deep end.
And I've got one lieutenant that wasn't real functional.
He had the mortar platoon and he was he was scared.
We've gotten all of them back and we're getting ready to withdraw
because we've been laying down covering fires, the rest of the company, and they closed behind us.
So now I've got about the six of us surrounded.
By this time, it is about 545 in the afternoon.
It is just about dark, and two more ARA birds come on the station.
We're unfortunate in that we're in a little bitty depression, about 18 inches deep and kind of an intermittent stream.
And he comes on and I said, I need you to lay these rockets about 10 feet on either side of me.
And I had a little strobe light so he could see me.
And he said, I can't lay it that close.
And I said, if you don't, it's not going to make any difference.
And he said, OK, I'm rolling hot.
And he brought those two birds in and put those rockets down like he laid a chalk line and just laid a string out of each side of that thing.
wingman came in right behind him and we picked up and hauled ass.
And that's the only reason I'm here today.
Tremendous job.
Those guys really did a great job.
Anyway, we got back to where the rest of the company was.
We had cut a place where we could evacuate our wounded from and the rest of what was left of us wagon wheeled and licked our wounds.
and they dumped 2,000 rounds of artillery into that place that night, and the next morning three companies moved into the area.
Most of the NVA had evacuated, but what we found was the staging area for the 69 tele-offensive.
It didn't happen, because we stumbled into the staging area for it.
Now, they weren't prepared to do another 68, but they were going to do a 69.
We found
A whole headquarters complete with radios and mimeograph machines.
They hauled rockets and stuff out of there for a week and then they finally blew what was left in place because I couldn't afford any more blade time to haul it out.
But, it cost me 52 guys out of my company.
You know, they weren't all dead, but either dead or wounded.
52 guys.
Now, I normally went to the field with somewhere around, oh, 110 to 115.
Now, I left the company the next day to go on R&R.
Now, that hurt.
I came back a week later and was the battalion intelligence officer.
I had the same unit.
But that was not a good time to leave.
When you returned to the state, before I go on, how did you feel about the policy that was being used?
When I first went to Vietnam, we were there to protect the Vietnamese government from being overrun.
And early on in the stage, the Vietnamese government was losing about two battalions a month.
you could sit down there and mathematically count on basically how long the government was going to last on a logarithmic curve.
We pretty much turned the war around in terms of defeating the guerrilla forces.
That doesn't mean we found all of them, but we had stopped the horrendous losses that the Arvin army was taking.
Then they brought in the NVA, where they could come down out the borders, come in, raid, make assaults, move back across the borders.

I suppose the situation was very similar to some of the problems that they had in Korea, but it didn't take a tactical genius to figure out that if they had a line that they could cross where we couldn't follow them, we couldn't win.
I maintained, as a young captain, not being privy to all of the problems that the government was looking at, that we should have mobilized the country as a whole.
Number one, to ensure that the country was together.
And two, we should have taken the war to Vietnam, or North Vietnam.
And three, there should have been no safe areas.
If they go in there, we go after them.
I found once an American POW camp in Cambodia that they would not let me go after.

I had gone into Cambodia after being, after chasing some guys up to the river, and I left my company and took three volunteers with me, which I got chewed out for later, and went across the river and found an American, a very small one, but an American POW
and they would not let me go get it because it was in Cambodia and it was off limits.
Six months later, when Nixon authorized American troops to go into Cambodia, that Pildokia camp had been moved.
And I couldn't bust it with three guys.
Do you feel bitter about the way the government did it?
I don't know whether bitter is the right word.
I think that
before we get involved in any more conflicts, that we need to make a hard, cold decision whether we want to win.
And if so, we need to take the appropriate steps to do that.
If not, stay the hell out of it.
We basically lost 55,000 guys for nothing.
Do you feel the war was winnable?
I don't know.
I think we had a better shot at it than we did if they had turned us loose.
The problem is that we were trying to hold up a government that was corrupt, inept, and doomed to failure.
The war was probably winnable,
but I think it was only winnable if we took over the government and rebuilt it much like we did in Japan after the Second World War.
To prop up the government as it existed was doomed to failure because it did not have the popular support of the people.
The Communists did not have the popular support of the people either in terms of percentages.
Most of the people just wanted to be left alone.
The government would come in in the daylight and take their number one son and half their rice, and the NVA would come in at night, take the number two son and the other half of the rice.
The poor guys were left in the middle.
But Vietnam damn near destroyed American service.
It took us eight to ten years to put the Army back together.
The officer corps at the end of 75 was bitter, disillusioned.
There was a widespread movement for a while amongst the troops to unionize, which had some support from the general officer corps.
It was not a fun time.
Most of the troops felt betrayed.
And it was probably not until the late 70s, early 80s that we finally got the NCO Corps and the officer corps put back together.
One of the problems we had from, oh, 68 on was that the Army had expanded so fast that we didn't have the NCO Corps.
We made, at least in the Army, I don't know what the Marines did, what they called jokingly as the Shake and Bake MCO Academy.
And basically they ran an OCS for NCOs.
They would send them down to Fort Benning, and we would turn out either E-5s or E-6s in eight weeks.
You'd take a kid who did well on his basic qualifying scores, on his initial entrance examinations into the military,
And he did fairly well in basic and AIT.
They would send him to Fort Benning, running through the NCO Academy, and he would come out as an E-5 in the top, I think, 5% or 6% got to be E-6s.
For what they had to do and the training they had, they did an outstanding job.
but they still didn't have the 10 years of experience in dealing with people that we expected from most of our NCOs.
On several occasions as a company commander in Vietnam, I had E-4s run in platoons.
Considering what we had to work with, they did an outstanding job.
I know of no other army in the world that you can decimate your
nco ranks and end up with corporals and e4s and e5s taking over e7's jobs what do you feel about what's more while i was at the commander general staff college at fort leavenworth
We had a number of general officers come to speak.
Most of these were required attendants, although most of us were probably gone anyway.
Westmoreland, after he had retired, showed up as a visiting guest speaker, not required attendance, basically hawking his book.
It was scheduled after class hours.
at four o'clock in the afternoon, and of the 800 odd majors and lieutenant colonels in that class, about 150 of us showed up.
Leavenworth is unique in that, that and the War College, there is a policy that when you get visiting officers in,
there is no such thing as rank.
You can ask any question.
It cannot be done in an impolite manner, but what is said in those rooms, stay in those rooms.
Westmoreland went on about his book and why he thought that some of our political decisions were incorrect.
And a young major who had, and all of us had served under Westmoreland, asked him if he was so opposed to the
what was going on over there.
Why did he not resign in protest to make a statement?
And his answer was, well, he thought he could do better staying there.
At which time, better than half of the 150 of us got up and walked out.
I'm not sure that answers your question.
When you left Vietnam,
When you came back and you became a student with the Army, tell me where you went and your experiences there.
Well, you know that I was enlisted before I got commissioned.
I became well aware of that in my second tour.
If I wanted to stay in the service, a degree was an absolute requirement.
And I wrote a letter back to the Department of the Army stating at the end of my tour in Vietnam,

I was eligible to get out of the army or if I extended I was eligible for reassignment and I basically told them that at the end of that tour I was going back to school if I had to go back as a civilian I would and then I would come back in later but I would like to apply for what was called the bootstrap program at that point in time or the pilot program for the bootstrap I didn't hear anything I didn't hear anything I didn't hear anything
I told you about the day that I was due to go on R&R, and after having lost these 52 guys, I'm sitting in a hole.
I've got water up to my knees.
My morale was, I feel like I have, I've really done something bad.
At this point in time, I don't know that I've run into a regiment that I didn't have a chance.
I think I really screwed up and cost a whole bunch of people their lives.
the mail bird comes in and I get a letter from Jerry and some correspondence from Axel and a long letter from the Department of Army basically stating that if I want to I can go back to college.
At the end of that tour I went back to Adams State College in Colorado which is a small teaching college
that has a pretty decent business department.
And I went to that one because they were the first one that sent me back a letter saying, yeah, we'll accept you and you can complete your four years of school in less than 24 months.
